talk.author: did:plc:pay7hbhmgcfitub4umyeghl6
talk.utter: I hope you continue to use this budding one, in place of the other site, Wataru.  One thing I miss about the Great Transition is that a number of Japan side voices don't want to give up the clicks and hits over there.  Aren't even making the effort to cross-post, which takes seconds.

talk.author: did:plc:ybgdrhv6yucoygebyovsu2ba
talk.utter: There are actually four candidates: Xitter, Mastodon, Bluesky, and Threads. It's hard to see me choosing Threads, but Mastodon is still a strong contender and lets me follow accounts on Bluesky and Threads that choose to federate. The main advantage of X is so many of my Japanese friends use it.

talk.author: did:plc:pay7hbhmgcfitub4umyeghl6
talk.utter: I have a Mastodon, but the feed doesn't hum.  So I forget to go there--nothing is going on!  Tax return prospects contact me there, and I got some business too.  But embarrassingly, I answer others really later.  I wish that the "big" J-posters would come here, but they start lower, I think. 2/

talk.author: did:plc:pay7hbhmgcfitub4umyeghl6
talk.utter: 2/  GaijinMommy made a successful leap and gets her usual count-by-the-dozen likes and hits.  But the others, I think, feel burned by Famichiki Mastodon, and so still hug tight to a social media platform that's run by a multi-billionaire using it to twist public opinion and silence certain ideas.

talk.author: did:plc:pay7hbhmgcfitub4umyeghl6
talk.utter: In my view, it didnt (hasn’t!) reached critical mass.  A lot of great Japan-side expats on Famichki, and ex-“X” posters on Mastodon.  But the feed doesn’t hum.  At least for me.
